dialogs.original: Philemon, ho!
dialogs.translated: Hey, Philemon!

dialogs.original: Doth my lord call?
dialogs.translated: Did you call me, sir?

dialogs.original: Get fire and meat for these poor men:'T has been a turbulent and stormy night.
dialogs.translated: Start a fire and get some food for these poor men. It's been a rough and stormy night.

dialogs.original: I have been in many; but such a night as this,Till now, I ne'er endured.
dialogs.translated: I've been in many storms, but, until now, I've never seen a night as bad as this.

dialogs.original: Your master will be dead ere you return;There's nothing can be minister'd to natureThat can recover him.  [TO PHILEMON]  Give this to the 'pothecary,And tell me how it works.
dialogs.translated: Your master will be dead before you get back; there's no way on earth to help him now.[To PHILEMON] Give this to the doctor, and tell me how it works.

dialogs.original: Good morrow.
dialogs.translated: Good morning.

dialogs.original: Good morrow to your lordship.
dialogs.translated: Good morning, sir.

dialogs.original: Gentlemen,Why do you stir so early?
dialogs.translated: Gentleman, what are you doing up so early?

dialogs.original: Sir,    Our lodgings, standing bleak upon the sea,    Shook as the earth did quake;    The very principals did seem to rend,    And all-to topple: pure surprise and fear    Made me to quit the house.
dialogs.translated: Sir, our house, which overlooks the sea, shook in the earthquake. It seemed like the foundation itself was breaking and that the whole building would split in two! It scared us enough that we left quickly.

dialogs.original: That is the cause we trouble you so early;'Tis not our husbandry.
dialogs.translated: That's why we're bothering you so earlyit's not our fault.

dialogs.original: O, you say well.
dialogs.translated: Fair enough.

dialogs.original: But I much marvel that your lordship, having    Rich tire about you, should at these early hours    Shake off the golden slumber of repose.    'Tis most strange,    Nature should be so conversant with pain,    Being thereto not compell'd.
dialogs.translated: But I'm surprised that someone as rich and well-provided as you is awake at this hour. It's odd that you'd want to sacrifice sleep when you don't have to.

dialogs.original: I hold it ever,    Virtue and cunning were endowments greater    Than nobleness and riches:   careless heirs    May the two latter darken and expend;    But immortality attends the former.    Making a man a god.   'Tis known, I ever    Have studied physic, through which secret art,    By turning o'er authorities, I have,    Together with my practise,   made familiar    To me and to my aid the blest infusions    That dwell in vegetives, in metals, stones;    And I can speak of the disturbances    That nature works, and of her cures;   which doth give me    A more content in course of true delight    Than to be thirsty after tottering honour,    Or tie my treasure up in silken bags,    To please the fool and death.
dialogs.translated: I truly believe that virtue and wisdom are more important to have than status and wealth. Careless children can ruin and waste the latter, but the former last forever, making humans like gods. As everyone knows, I've studied medicine for a long time, the secrets of which I've discovered through reading old experts and through my own experience. I'm now familiar with the powerful potions to be found in plants, metals, and stones. And I can talk about the good and bad that Nature is capable of, all of which I enjoy this a lot more than I would trying to earn money or win other people's approval; that's totally worthless.

dialogs.original: Your honour has through Ephesus pour'd forth    Your charity, and hundreds call themselves    Your creatures, who by you have been restored:    And not your knowledge, your personal pain, but even    Your purse, still open, hath built Lord Cerimon    Such strong renown as time shall ne'er decay.
dialogs.translated: Sir, you've been generous here in Ephesus. Thousands of people have been cured by you and are loyal to you. Not only your knowledge and your personal effort, but also your charity, Lord Cerimon, have built a reputation that will last forever.

dialogs.original: So; lift there.
dialogs.translated: Put it up there.

dialogs.original: What is that?
dialogs.translated: What is that?

dialogs.original: Sir, even nowDid the sea toss upon our shore this chest:'Tis of some wreck.
dialogs.translated: Sir, this chest washed up on the shore from a shipwreck.

dialogs.original: Set 't down, let's look upon't.
dialogs.translated: Set it down; let's look at it.

dialogs.original: 'Tis like a coffin, sir.
dialogs.translated: It looks like a coffin, sir.

dialogs.original: Whate'er it be,    'Tis wondrous heavy.   Wrench it open straight:    If the sea's stomach be o'ercharged with gold,    'Tis a good constraint of fortune it belches upon us.
dialogs.translated: Whatever it is, it's very heavy. Open it up quick! If there's too much gold laying on the ocean floor, it's good luck that the sea has thrown it up to us.

dialogs.original: 'Tis so, my lord.
dialogs.translated: Of course, sir.

dialogs.original: How close 'tis caulk'd and bitumed!Did the sea cast it up?
dialogs.translated: It's really sealed up tight! Did it come out of the sea?

dialogs.original: I never saw so huge a billow, sir,As toss'd it upon shore.
dialogs.translated: The biggest wave I've ever seen washed it up on the shore.

dialogs.original: Wrench it open;Soft! it smells most sweetly in my sense.
dialogs.translated: Open it! [They succeed in loosening the lid of the chest] Shh! I smell something sweet.

dialogs.original: A delicate odour.
dialogs.translated: A delicate odor.

dialogs.original: As ever hit my nostril. So, up with it.O you most potent gods! what's here? a corse!
dialogs.translated: The most delicate I've ever smelled. Lift up the lid! Oh, you powerful gods! What's in here? [He looks in] A body!

dialogs.original: Most strange!
dialogs.translated: How strange!

dialogs.original: Shrouded in cloth of state; balm'd and entreasured    With full bags of spices! A passport too!    Apollo, perfect me in the characters!     [Reading from a scroll]     'Here I give to understand,    If e'er this coffin drive a-land,    I, King Pericles, have lost    This queen, worth all our mundane cost.    Who finds her, give her burying;    She was the daughter of a king:    Besides this treasure for a fee,    The gods requite his charity!'    If thou livest, Pericles, thou hast a heart    That even cracks for woe! This chanced tonight.
dialogs.translated: Wearing royal clothes, scented with perfumes and spices! With a passport, too! Apollo, help me read what this says. [He picks up a scroll and reads from it]  "To whoever's reading this, if this coffin ever comes to land: I, King Pericles, have lost my beloved wife. If you've found her, please give her a proper burial. She was the daughter of the king. Take this gold as payment for your service. May the gods bless you!"[To the absent Pericles] Pericles, if you're alive, I feel sorry for you. She must have died tonight.

dialogs.original: Most likely, sir.
dialogs.translated: Most likely, sir.

dialogs.original: Nay, certainly to-night;    For look how fresh she looks! They were too rough    That threw her in the sea.   Make a fire within:    Fetch hither all my boxes in my closet.
dialogs.translated: No, definitely tonight, look how fresh she looks! They shouldn't have thrown her in the sea. Build a fire inside, and bring all the boxes from my closet.

dialogs.original: Death may usurp on nature many hours,    And yet the fire of life kindle again    The o'erpress'd spirits.   I heard of an Egyptian    That had nine hours lien dead,    Who was by good appliance recovered.
dialogs.translated: It may look like someone is dead for hours, but then they revive and come back to life. I heard of an Egyptian who was dead for nine hours and then, with some help, recovered.

dialogs.original: Well said, well said; the fire and cloths.    The rough and woeful music that we have,    Cause it to sound, beseech you.    The viol once more: how thou stirr'st, thou block!    The music there!   I pray you, give her air.    Gentlemen.    This queen will live: nature awakes; a warmth    Breathes out of her:   she hath not been entranced    Above five hours: see how she gins to blow    Into life's flower again!
dialogs.translated: [To the servants] Perfect, perfect. Give me the fire and the clothes. Play some sad music, please! Play that violin, you lazy man! Music, please, give her some music. [The servants begin to play while Cerimon uses various medicines and potions on THAISA][To the GENTLEMEN] Gentlemen. The queen will live. Look, she's waking up! She's warm! She's been asleep for about five hours, but look how she comes back to life!

dialogs.original: The heavens,Through you, increase our wonder and set upYour fame forever.
dialogs.translated: The gods, through you, amaze us. You've secured your fame forever.

dialogs.original: She is alive; behold,    Her eyelids, cases to those heavenly jewels    Which Pericles hath lost,    Begin to part their fringes of bright gold;    The diamonds of a most praised water    Do appear, to make the world twice rich.   Live,    And make us weep to hear your fate, fair creature,    Rare as you seem to be.
dialogs.translated: She's alive! Look, her eyelids, which cover the beautiful eyes which Pericles has lost, are just beginning to separate their eyelashes. Now her sparkling eyes are appearingand what a treasure they are.[To THAISA] Live, and bring tears to our eyes with your sad story, beautiful lady. We can tell how special you are.

dialogs.original: O dear Diana,Where am I? Where's my lord? What world is this?
dialogs.translated: Oh, Diana, where am I? Where's my husband? What is this place?

dialogs.original: Is not this strange?
dialogs.translated: Isn't this strange?

dialogs.original: Most rare.
dialogs.translated: Very odd.

dialogs.original: Hush, my gentle neighbours!    Lend me your hands; to the next chamber bear her.    Get linen: now this matter must be look'd to,    For her relapse is mortal. Come, come;    And AEsculapius guide us!
dialogs.translated: Quiet, gentlemen! Please, pick her up and take her into the next room. Get some sheets; we need to hurry, since a relapse could kill her. Come, come, and Aesculapius help us!
